metadata.title: God save the queen / Sex Pistols
creator: Matlock Glen
Cook Paul
Jones Steve
Lydon John
Sex Pistols
metadata.source: Istituto Centrale per i Beni Sonori ed Audiovisivi

texts.kid-amateur-short: “God Save the Queen” is a famous song released in 1977 by the punk rock band Sex Pistols. It came out in the same year that Queen Elizabeth II celebrated 25 years on the throne. The song shocked many people because it criticized the monarchy and was even banned by the BBC. The cover showed a picture of the Queen with her eyes and mouth covered by bold words. At the same time, punk fashion was growing, and designer Vivienne Westwood helped make this new style visible through clothes and images.
texts.kid-amateur-long: “God Save the Queen” is a famous song released in 1977 by the punk rock band Sex Pistols. It came out in the same year that Queen Elizabeth II celebrated 25 years on the throne. The song shocked many people because it criticized the monarchy and was even banned by the BBC. The cover showed a picture of the Queen with her eyes and mouth covered by bold words. At the same time, punk fashion was growing, and designer Vivienne Westwood helped make this new style visible through clothes and images. Because the song was so different from traditional music, it became very popular with young people who felt angry or misunderstood. Punk music was loud, fast, and simple, and it talked about real problems instead of polite stories. The image on the cover became just as famous as the song. It looked rough and unfinished, breaking the rules of how records usually looked. Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren sold T-shirts in their London shop using the same image as the record cover. Wearing these shirts allowed young people to show that they did not agree with old rules and traditions. Through music and fashion together, “God Save the Queen” helped punk become a powerful way to express freedom, rebellion, and identity.
texts.kid-expert-short: Released in May 1977, “God Save the Queen” was the Sex Pistols’ second single and one of the most controversial songs in British history. Its lyrics criticized the monarchy during the Queen’s Silver Jubilee, leading to censorship and strong reactions from the media. The single’s artwork, created by Jamie Reid, altered a royal portrait using cut-out lettering, turning a symbol of authority into a sign of rebellion.
texts.kid-expert-long: Released in May 1977, “God Save the Queen” was the Sex Pistols’ second single and one of the most controversial songs in British history. Its lyrics criticized the monarchy during the Queen’s Silver Jubilee, leading to censorship and strong reactions from the media. The single’s artwork, created by Jamie Reid, altered a royal portrait using cut-out lettering, turning a symbol of authority into a sign of rebellion. This visual style was inspired by collage and protest art and was meant to look aggressive and unfinished. By changing the Queen’s image, the artwork questioned power and respect in a direct and shocking way. Vivienne Westwood used this same image on clothing sold in her shop, helping to bring punk ideas into everyday life. The clothes were not meant to be beautiful in a traditional sense but to make people think and react. Through this connection between music, art, and fashion, punk became more than a sound. It became a movement that allowed young people to challenge society and express their feelings openly.
texts.adult-amateur-short: “God Save the Queen” is a key 1977 punk single by the Sex Pistols, released during Queen Elizabeth II’s Silver Jubilee. Its direct attack on the monarchy caused widespread controversy and resulted in broadcast bans. The cover artwork, designed by Jamie Reid, transformed an official royal portrait into a provocative punk image. Vivienne Westwood’s adoption of this imagery in fashion linked the single to the visual identity of punk culture.
texts.adult-amateur-long: “God Save the Queen” is a key 1977 punk single by the Sex Pistols, released during Queen Elizabeth II’s Silver Jubilee. Its direct attack on the monarchy caused widespread controversy and resulted in broadcast bans. The cover artwork, designed by Jamie Reid, transformed an official royal portrait into a provocative punk image. Vivienne Westwood’s adoption of this imagery in fashion linked the single to the visual identity of punk culture. This connection between music and imagery helped the single reach far beyond record stores. Despite censorship, the song became extremely popular and is often remembered as the sound of a generation rejecting established authority. Reid’s graphic design broke with traditional record sleeves by using ransom-note typography and visual disruption, reinforcing the song’s confrontational message. Westwood, working closely with Malcolm McLaren, brought this same aesthetic into clothing through T-shirts sold in their boutique. These garments turned punk graphics into everyday statements, allowing wearers to publicly align themselves with anti-establishment values. Together, the song and its imagery show how punk used multiple creative fields to communicate a shared cultural message.
texts.adult-expert-short: “God Save the Queen” represents a crucial convergence of sound, graphic design, and fashion within punk culture. The single deploys visual and lyrical provocation to undermine institutional authority, particularly through the deliberate defacement of royal imagery. Vivienne Westwood’s engagement with this aesthetic demonstrates how punk’s visual language extended beyond music into design practice.
texts.adult-expert-long: “God Save the Queen” represents a crucial convergence of sound, graphic design, and fashion within punk culture. The single deploys visual and lyrical provocation to undermine institutional authority, particularly through the deliberate defacement of royal imagery. Vivienne Westwood’s engagement with this aesthetic demonstrates how punk’s visual language extended beyond music into design practice. Westwood’s translation of the single’s graphic language into fashion materialized most clearly in the “God Save the Queen” T-shirt, produced and sold in her boutique with Malcolm McLaren in 1977. The garment adopted Jamie Reid’s defaced royal portrait through screen-printing techniques that emphasized flatness, visual aggression, and immediacy rather than refinement. The T-shirt itself, a traditionally utilitarian and mass-produced item, was deliberately recontextualized as a political surface. Westwood exploited its associations with youth culture and everyday wear, using it as a canvas for dissent. Distressed finishes, provocative slogans, and confrontational iconography rejected conventional notions of taste, craftsmanship, and luxury that dominated British fashion at the time. This approach aligned with Westwood’s broader punk methodology, which privileged anti-construction, symbolic abrasion, and the exposure of process over tailored perfection. Garments were not designed to flatter the body or conform to established silhouettes but to communicate attitude, ideology, and resistance. By integrating Reid’s graphic détournement into wearable form, Westwood collapsed the boundaries between record sleeve, protest poster, and fashion object. The “God Save the Queen” T-shirt thus became a foundational example of fashion as visual rhetoric, positioning clothing as an active participant in punk’s challenge to cultural authority and redefining design practice as an explicitly political act.

texts.kid-amateur-short: The Westwood MacAndreas tartan is a special colorful check pattern made by Vivienne Westwood in 1993. It looks like the old Scottish tartans, but Vivienne gave it a fun, modern twist. She named it MacAndreas after her husband, Andreas Kronthaler. Tartans are made of criss‑crossed stripes, like a puzzle of colors that can be used on skirts, jackets, and scarves. Vivienne used her tartan on lots of clothes to make them look bold, exciting, and a little bit naughty — just like punk fashion!
texts.kid-amateur-long: The Westwood MacAndreas tartan is a special colorful check pattern made by Vivienne Westwood in 1993. It looks like the old Scottish tartans, but Vivienne gave it a fun, modern twist. She named it MacAndreas after her husband, Andreas Kronthaler. Tartans are made of criss‑crossed stripes, like a puzzle of colors that can be used on skirts, jackets, and scarves. Vivienne used her tartan on lots of clothes to make them look bold, exciting, and a little bit naughty — just like punk fashion! Vivienne wanted to take something old and make it new and exciting. She worked with expert Scottish weavers to create her very own tartan. In her fashion shows, she used the MacAndreas tartan on mini skirts, jackets, dresses, and scarves, sometimes mixing it with other patterns or materials. The clothes looked playful and surprising. Some had funny shapes, some were layered, and some had bright colors that really stood out. By wearing these clothes, people could show they were brave, creative, and liked to be different. The MacAndreas tartan became one of the special patterns everyone remembered from Vivienne’s shows. It showed that old, traditional things could be turned into something cool, bold, and full of personality.
texts.kid-expert-short: The MacAndreas tartan was made for Vivienne Westwood’s Anglomania Autumn/Winter 1993/94 collection and is officially recorded in the Scottish Register of Tartans. It was named after Andreas Kronthaler and used in striking outfits like kilts, jackets, and skirts. Vivienne’s design made this traditional pattern feel new, daring, and exciting, showing how fashion can be clever and creative.
texts.kid-expert-long: The MacAndreas tartan was made for Vivienne Westwood’s Anglomania Autumn/Winter 1993/94 collection and is officially recorded in the Scottish Register of Tartans. It was named after Andreas Kronthaler and used in striking outfits like kilts, jackets, and skirts. Vivienne’s design made this traditional pattern feel new, daring, and exciting, showing how fashion can be clever and creative. This tartan was not just any tartan — it was a special design by Vivienne herself. She made it with Scottish weavers so it could appear on all kinds of clothes. On the runway, she put it on jackets, skirts, mini kilts, and dresses, sometimes with other patterns mixed in. The clothes looked bold and different from anything normal. The tartan helped young people and fashion fans feel creative and brave. It became a famous pattern because Vivienne used it over and over in her shows. The MacAndreas tartan showed everyone that old, traditional things can be made new, fun, and full of personality when someone uses their imagination. It became part of the punk style that Vivienne loved so much.
texts.adult-amateur-short: The Westwood MacAndreas tartan is a registered designer tartan created by Vivienne Westwood in 1993 for her Anglomania Autumn/Winter 1993/94 collection. Named after Andreas Kronthaler, it was woven in Scotland and used repeatedly in her garments, including tailored jackets, mini kilts, skirts, and dresses. The tartan exemplifies Westwood’s approach of combining heritage textile patterns with contemporary punk-inspired design.
texts.adult-amateur-long: The Westwood MacAndreas tartan is a registered designer tartan created by Vivienne Westwood in 1993 for her Anglomania Autumn/Winter 1993/94 collection. Named after Andreas Kronthaler, it was woven in Scotland and used repeatedly in her garments, including tailored jackets, mini kilts, skirts, and dresses. The tartan exemplifies Westwood’s approach of combining heritage textile patterns with contemporary punk-inspired design. Vivienne Westwood’s MacAndreas tartan illustrates her signature strategy of transforming traditional fabrics into avant-garde fashion statements. In her Anglomania AW 1993/94 collection, she applied the tartan to tailored jackets, asymmetric skirts, and layered ensembles, often contrasting it with unexpected fabrics or cuts. Its repeated presence in subsequent collections reinforced its status as a signature motif. By integrating a historical Scottish textile into garments that played with proportion, structure, and layering, Westwood showed how a designer could reinterpret heritage with a bold, contemporary eye. The tartan’s use in multiple runway collections made it both a visual anchor and a symbol of her punk-influenced design philosophy, blending tradition with rebellion.
texts.adult-expert-short: The MacAndreas tartan is a study in heritage reinterpretation and sartorial subversion. By registering it as her own, Westwood claimed authorship over a traditional textile, turning it into a recurring design element across multiple collections. Its application on kilts, jackets, tailored skirts, and layered outfits illustrates her deliberate blending of historical reference with punk and avant-garde fashion language.
texts.adult-expert-long: The MacAndreas tartan is a study in heritage reinterpretation and sartorial subversion. By registering it as her own, Westwood claimed authorship over a traditional textile, turning it into a recurring design element across multiple collections. Its application on kilts, jackets, tailored skirts, and layered outfits illustrates her deliberate blending of historical reference with punk and avant-garde fashion language. The MacAndreas tartan occupies a central role in Westwood’s exploration of textile heritage within contemporary fashion. Initially featured in Anglomania AW 1993/94, it reappeared in subsequent collections, including AW 1994, Punkature, and later runway shows, often layered, pleated, or cut asymmetrically to interact with her signature silhouettes. Westwood utilized techniques such as pattern direction manipulation, asymmetric tailoring, layering, and distressed finishes to challenge the static associations of tartan with formal Scottish attire. Screen-printed and woven versions of the MacAndreas tartan adorned mini kilts, tailored jackets, corsetry, dresses, and layered ensembles, transforming it into a vehicle for visual and cultural subversion. By juxtaposing the tartan with contrasting fabrics and unconventional cuts, Westwood destabilized expectations of symmetry, polish, and historical fidelity, asserting designer authorship over both pattern and garment structure. Through its repeated presence on the runway, the MacAndreas tartan became a signature emblem of Westwood’s design philosophy, exemplifying how a heritage textile can be elevated to a political and stylistic statement within fashion, blending Scottish tradition, punk ethos, and couture-level construction.

texts.kid-amateur-short: The “God Save the Queen” top is a famous T-shirt made by Vivienne Westwood with her partner Malcolm McLarenin the late 1970s. It has a big picture on the front that shows Queen Elizabeth II with a safety pin on her face, making it look wild and rebellious, just like punk music and fashion were back then. The design comes from the artwork used on the Sex Pistols record “God Save the Queen,” and it helped make this shirt one of the most famous punk clothes ever. People wore it to show they questioned old rules and liked bold, different styles.
texts.kid-amateur-long: The “God Save the Queen” top is a famous T-shirt made by Vivienne Westwood with her partner Malcolm McLarenin the late 1970s. It has a big picture on the front that shows Queen Elizabeth II with a safety pin on her face, making it look wild and rebellious, just like punk music and fashion were back then. The design comes from the artwork used on the Sex Pistols record “God Save the Queen,” and it helped make this shirt one of the most famous punk clothes ever. People wore it to show they questioned old rules and liked bold, different styles. Vivienne and Malcolm made the T-shirt in London and sold it in their punk shop called Seditionaries. The shirt was meant for young people who loved punk music and the loud, fierce look that came with it. It was not plain like most T-shirts: the seams and edges were made to look rough on purpose, and the big picture on the front stood out strongly against the white cotton. The picture shows the Queen with a safety pin on her face and the words around her, just like in the punk song that shouted “God Save the Queen”. Wearing this shirt was a statement; it told everyone, “I want to do things my own way!”. It was exciting and shocking to many people at the time. This top became very famous because it mixed music, fashion, and rebellion all in one piece of clothing. It helped make punk style something that lots of people around the world remember even today.
texts.kid-expert-short: The God Save the Queen T-shirt was made by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren in the late 1970s, inspired by the artwork created for the Sex Pistols’ song of the same name. It was sold in their London shop, Seditionaries, and became a bold symbol of the punk subculture. The shirt’s graphic image, featuring an altered portrait of Queen Elizabeth II with a safety pin, shocked the public and helped define the raw, rebellious look of early punk fashion.
texts.kid-expert-long: The God Save the Queen T-shirt was made by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren in the late 1970s, inspired by the artwork created for the Sex Pistols’ song of the same name. It was sold in their London shop, Seditionaries, and became a bold symbol of the punk subculture. The shirt’s graphic image, featuring an altered portrait of Queen Elizabeth II with a safety pin, shocked the public and helped define the raw, rebellious look of early punk fashion. This top is not like a regular T-shirt; its design uses a strong picture that was made to represent how punk rock musicians and fans felt about society and rules in the 1970s. The image came from the iconic artwork of the Sex Pistols’ single God Save the Queen, which was meant to surprise and even upset people. On the shirt, the Queen’s face is changed by a safety pin, and words from the song are arranged around her, showing how punk artists mixed clothes and music to express their ideas. Vivienne and Malcolm sold this shirt at their Seditionaries shop on King’s Road, and people who wore it showed that they wanted to stand out and be different. The rough edges and bold design made it part of punk culture, a style that said “We do things in our own way”. Because of this, the top became one of the most famous pieces of punk fashion ever made.
texts.adult-amateur-short: The God Save the Queen top is a seminal punk T-shirt designed by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren in the late 1970s, most notably sold through their Seditionaries boutique in London. Its graphic, based on Jamie Reid’s lithography for the Sex Pistols God Save the Queen, intentionally subverts established imagery of monarchy to produce a confrontational visual statement. This top became an emblem of early British punk fashion, blending music, visual art, and clothing into a single provocative cultural artefact.
texts.adult-amateur-long: The God Save the Queen top is a seminal punk T-shirt designed by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren in the late 1970s, most notably sold through their Seditionaries boutique in London. Its graphic, based on Jamie Reid’s lithography for the Sex Pistols God Save the Queen, intentionally subverts established imagery of monarchy to produce a confrontational visual statement. This top became an emblem of early British punk fashion, blending music, visual art, and clothing into a single provocative cultural artefact. The God Save the Queen top occupies a central place in the history of punk design as one of the earliest and most influential examples of fashion’s engagement with subculture and political critique. Created in the late 1970s by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren, the shirt was sold at Seditionaries, their boutique on King’s Road, a crucible for punk aesthetics, cultural exchange, and anti-establishment design experimentation. The graphic derives directly from Jamie Reid’s lithographic treatment for the Sex Pistols’ God Save the Queen single, a defaced portrait of Queen Elizabeth II that became synonymous with punk’s challenge to national authority and popular imagery. By transposing this visual onto cotton knitwear, Westwood transformed political provocation into wearable iconography. The top’s intentional roughness, including raw seams, visible stitching, and distressed surfaces, aligned it with punk’s broader rejection of polished fashion norms and its embrace of anti-fashion gestures that foregrounded material disruption over conventional refinement. This design not only articulated punk’s visual language in garment form but also helped establish a template for how fashion could engage directly with music, youth identity, and visual culture, making the T-shirt itself a potent cultural artefact that echoed across subsequent decades of style and performance art.
texts.adult-expert-short: The God Save the Queen top exemplifies cross-disciplinary design strategies at the intersection of fashion, graphic art, and subcultural expression. Its appropriation of Jamie Reid’s subversive lithography onto cotton knitwear illustrates Vivienne Westwood’s early exploration of design as visual critique, where surface and structure are deployed to challenge established cultural narratives.
texts.adult-expert-long: The God Save the Queen top exemplifies cross-disciplinary design strategies at the intersection of fashion, graphic art, and subcultural expression. Its appropriation of Jamie Reid’s subversive lithography onto cotton knitwear illustrates Vivienne Westwood’s early exploration of design as visual critique, where surface and structure are deployed to challenge established cultural narratives. The God Save the Queen top is a defining artifact in the evolution of punk fashion as a disciplined design practice, in which clothing becomes an active medium of cultural critique rather than passive ornamentation. Emerging from the milieu of the Seditionaries boutique circa 1976–1977, it represents a deliberate appropriation of Jamie Reid’s graphic lexicon, a defaced royal portrait interwoven with provocative text, as a surface strategy applied to knitwear. This shirt’s design logic reflects Westwood’s early interrogation of fashion’s role in transmitting ideology: the deliberate visibility of seams and raw edges speaks to a constructional aesthetic that privileges disruption and anti-aesthetic rhetoric over the polished silhouettes typical of mainstream collections of the era. Such techniques prefigure later punk-influenced looks on runway and in couture, where the boundaries between garment and graphic artifact blur. Within the context of late 1970s London, God Save the Queen operated not merely as apparel but as a mobile graphic statement, worn by musicians, performers, and youth culture figures who foregrounded resistance through fashion. Its presence in key institutional collections today underscores its significance as an early exemplar of fashion’s capacity to engage with political and cultural narratives.

texts.kid-amateur-short: The SEX earring is a small but very bold piece of jewelry designed by Vivienne Westwood in the early 1990s. It has the word “SEX” written in big letters, which made many people surprised when they first saw it. Vivienne loved using words and symbols to make people stop and think. This earring shows how punk fashion was not afraid to be loud, cheeky, and different. Even something tiny, like an earring, could send a strong message.
texts.kid-amateur-long: The SEX earring is a small but very bold piece of jewelry designed by Vivienne Westwood in the early 1990s. It has the word “SEX” written in big letters, which made many people surprised when they first saw it. Vivienne loved using words and symbols to make people stop and think. This earring shows how punk fashion was not afraid to be loud, cheeky, and different. Even something tiny, like an earring, could send a strong message. Vivienne believed that clothes and accessories could talk, just like music or art. That is why she chose a word that was usually considered rude or secret and turned it into something you could wear proudly. The SEX earring was worn by people who liked punk style and wanted to show they were brave and not afraid of rules. It was often paired with other bold clothes, like ripped shirts, safety pins, or colorful outfits. By making jewelry with strong words, Vivienne showed that fashion did not have to be quiet or polite. The SEX earring became a symbol of punk ideas: freedom, rebellion, and the courage to be yourself.
texts.kid-expert-short: The SEX earring, designed by Vivienne Westwood around 1992–93, is an example of how punk ideas appeared even in small fashion items. Using a provocative word as decoration, Westwood challenged traditional ideas about beauty and politeness. The earring became a recognizable punk symbol, proving that accessories could be just as powerful as clothes in expressing identity.
texts.kid-expert-long: The SEX earring, designed by Vivienne Westwood around 1992–93, is an example of how punk ideas appeared even in small fashion items. Using a provocative word as decoration, Westwood challenged traditional ideas about beauty and politeness. The earring became a recognizable punk symbol, proving that accessories could be just as powerful as clothes in expressing identity. In punk fashion, words were often used like pictures. Vivienne Westwood understood this very well and turned language into a design element. The SEX earring was not meant to shock just for fun; it was meant to question why certain words were forbidden or uncomfortable. By wearing it, people showed that they were not afraid of breaking social rules. This earring appeared together with other bold Westwood designs and became part of a punk look that mixed humor, rebellion, and confidence. It showed that fashion could be playful and serious at the same time, even when it was very small.
texts.adult-amateur-short: The SEX earring, designed by Vivienne Westwood in the early 1990s, exemplifies punk’s use of language as a visual and political tool. By transforming a taboo word into wearable jewelry, Westwood challenged conventions of taste, propriety, and adornment. The piece demonstrates how punk symbolism extended beyond garments into accessories, reinforcing fashion as a medium of cultural provocation.
texts.adult-amateur-long: The SEX earring, designed by Vivienne Westwood in the early 1990s, exemplifies punk’s use of language as a visual and political tool. By transforming a taboo word into wearable jewelry, Westwood challenged conventions of taste, propriety, and adornment. The piece demonstrates how punk symbolism extended beyond garments into accessories, reinforcing fashion as a medium of cultural provocation. Westwood’s SEX earring reflects her long-standing engagement with provocative typography and confrontational messaging. Small in scale but high in impact, the earring distills punk ideology into a single word rendered as ornament. Rather than serving a purely decorative function, the piece operates as a statement object, aligning the wearer with anti-establishment values and freedom of expression. The earring was worn by figures connected to punk and alternative fashion scenes, including musicians, performers, and models associated with Westwood’s circle, reinforcing its role as a visible marker of subcultural identity. By elevating language to the status of jewelry, Westwood blurred the boundary between graphic design and personal adornment, demonstrating how even accessories could communicate ideology and attitude within punk fashion.
texts.adult-expert-short: The SEX earring functions as a semiotic device within Vivienne Westwood’s design practice, using typography as material. Its blunt textual form challenges traditional hierarchies of refinement in jewelry, aligning accessories with punk’s broader rejection of polite aesthetics and passive consumption.
texts.adult-expert-long: The SEX earring functions as a semiotic device within Vivienne Westwood’s design practice, using typography as material. Its blunt textual form challenges traditional hierarchies of refinement in jewelry, aligning accessories with punk’s broader rejection of polite aesthetics and passive consumption. Within Westwood’s runway collections of the early 1990s, accessories such as the SEX earring played a crucial role in completing the punk-inflected narrative of the look. Appearing alongside deconstructed tailoring, slogan-based garments, and historical references, the earring functioned as a concentrated symbol of confrontation. From a design perspective, the piece redefines jewelry as graphic punctuation rather than embellishment. Its typographic clarity mirrors Westwood’s continued interest in text-based fashion, seen across collections that merged political language, erotic provocation, and historical critique. On the runway, such accessories amplified the ideological content of the garments, ensuring that even minimal elements contributed to the overall message. The SEX earring, worn with tailored jackets, corsetry, or layered ensembles, reinforced the idea that punk operates through accumulative visual signals rather than isolated statements. As part of Westwood’s wider design system, the earring exemplifies how small-scale objects can carry disproportionate cultural weight, transforming jewelry into an active participant in fashion’s discourse on power, morality, and self-expression.

texts.kid-amateur-short: This photograph shows Vivienne Westwood dressed like the Queen of England. It was taken in 1988 by the photographer Angus McBean. Vivienne is wearing a big fancy dress and a special hat that she designed herself. She looks serious, but the picture is also funny and playful. Vivienne liked dressing up to make people think and smile at the same time.
texts.kid-amateur-long: This photograph shows Vivienne Westwood dressed like the Queen of England. It was taken in 1988 by the photographer Angus McBean. Vivienne is wearing a big fancy dress and a special hat that she designed herself. She looks serious, but the picture is also funny and playful. Vivienne liked dressing up to make people think and smile at the same time. Vivienne loved costumes and pretending. In this photo, she dresses like a queen to play with ideas of power and tradition. But she does not copy the Queen exactly; she adds her own style. The hat she wears is one of her designs, showing that fashion can be creative and full of ideas. By dressing this way, Vivienne shows that clothes can tell stories. She wanted people to ask questions: Who decides what is important? Can fashion be funny and serious together? This photograph shows how Vivienne used clothes and accessories to express her personality and her ideas.
texts.kid-expert-short: In this photograph by Angus McBean, Vivienne Westwood dresses as the Queen of England while wearing a hat of her own design. The image mixes respect and humor, showing how Vivienne liked to challenge tradition. It represents her playful but thoughtful approach to fashion and identity.
texts.kid-expert-long: In this photograph by Angus McBean, Vivienne Westwood dresses as the Queen of England while wearing a hat of her own design. The image mixes respect and humor, showing how Vivienne liked to challenge tradition. It represents her playful but thoughtful approach to fashion and identity. Vivienne Westwood often used costumes to talk about history and power. In this photo, she dresses like the Queen, but with a twist that makes the image playful and ironic. The hat is important because it shows her role as a designer, not just a character. By mixing royal clothes with her own fashion ideas, Vivienne shows that tradition can be changed and reimagined. The photograph helps us understand that fashion is not only about clothes, but also about ideas, imagination, and confidence.
texts.adult-amateur-short: This 1988 photograph by Angus McBean portrays Vivienne Westwood dressed as the Queen of England while wearing a hat of her own design. The image captures Westwood’s irreverent relationship with British tradition, blending homage, irony, and self-authorship. It highlights her use of dress as a tool for cultural commentary.
texts.adult-amateur-long: This 1988 photograph by Angus McBean portrays Vivienne Westwood dressed as the Queen of England while wearing a hat of her own design. The image captures Westwood’s irreverent relationship with British tradition, blending homage, irony, and self-authorship. It highlights her use of dress as a tool for cultural commentary. Angus McBean’s portrait presents Vivienne Westwood in full royal costume, yet the image is far from straightforward imitation. By placing herself in the role of the monarch, Westwood stages a visual dialogue between authority and dissent. The inclusion of a hat designed by Westwood herself is central: it asserts her identity as a fashion designer intervening directly within the symbols of British power. This photograph reflects her ability to use clothing and accessories as conceptual devices, transforming fashion into a form of visual critique. The result is an image that is both celebratory and subversive, encapsulating Westwood’s complex relationship with heritage.
texts.adult-expert-short: The photograph functions as a constructed fashion portrait, in which Westwood performs British identity through costume. By occupying the visual language of monarchy while inserting her own design, the hat, she asserts authorship over tradition, turning fashion into a critical medium.
texts.adult-expert-long: The photograph functions as a constructed fashion portrait, in which Westwood performs British identity through costume. By occupying the visual language of monarchy while inserting her own design, the hat, she asserts authorship over tradition, turning fashion into a critical medium. Angus McBean’s 1988 portrait of Vivienne Westwood operates at the intersection of fashion, performance, and national symbolism. By dressing as the Queen of England, Westwood engages directly with the visual codes of British authority, yet the gesture is deliberately destabilized through exaggeration and self-awareness. Crucially, the hat she wears, designed by Westwood herself, functions as a sartorial signature. In fashion terms, the accessory disrupts the historical costume by inserting contemporary authorship into a traditionally codified ensemble. This act aligns with Westwood’s broader design practice, in which historical references are not reproduced faithfully but reworked through cut, proportion, and concept. The photograph mirrors her runway approach, where heritage garments are recontextualized to expose their ideological foundations. Rather than parody alone, the image articulates a complex stance: reverence for British tailoring and ceremony combined with a punk-informed impulse to question power. Through costume, styling, and accessory design, Westwood transforms portraiture into a fashion statement that collapses the boundaries between designer, subject, and symbol.

texts.kid-amateur-short: These studded shoes were designed by Vivienne Westwood in 1974, right at the start of punk fashion. They have metal studs all over them, which made them look strong, bold, and a little bit wild. Back then, most shoes were simple, but these looked very different and exciting. People who loved punk style wore them to show they didn’t want to follow old fashion rules. These shoes helped make punk fashion famous around the world.
texts.kid-amateur-long: These studded shoes were designed by Vivienne Westwood in 1974, right at the start of punk fashion. They have metal studs all over them, which made them look strong, bold, and a little bit wild. Back then, most shoes were simple, but these looked very different and exciting. People who loved punk style wore them to show they didn’t want to follow old fashion rules. These shoes helped make punk fashion famous around the world. Vivienne Westwood created these shoes when she and Malcolm McLaren ran a shop in London that sold clothes for young people who wanted to be different. The shop was important in the beginning of punk culture, where music, art, and fashion all mixed together. Most shoes at the time were plain, but these had shiny metal studs attached to them, making them look loud and noticeable. Kids who liked punk music and bold clothes wore them with ripped pants, leather jackets, and colorful hair. By adding studs - something usually seen on belts or jackets - to shoes, Vivienne made footwear that felt rebellious and powerful. These studded shoes were part of the first wave of punk fashion, helping young people show that they wanted clothes that matched their energy and ideas.
texts.kid-expert-short: The studded shoes from 1974 are one of Vivienne Westwood’s earliest fashion designs connected to punk. Instead of plain footwear, she added metal studs to give them a bold look. This design helped punk style spread because people saw that even shoes could be exciting and different. They became part of the story of how Vivienne changed the way people thought about clothing.
texts.kid-expert-long: The studded shoes from 1974 are one of Vivienne Westwood’s earliest fashion designs connected to punk. Instead of plain footwear, she added metal studs to give them a bold look. This design helped punk style spread because people saw that even shoes could be exciting and different. They became part of the story of how Vivienne changed the way people thought about clothing. In the 1970s, Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren were at the center of a new movement that mixed music and fashion in powerful ways. Their shop in London became a place where young people came to express their ideas through clothes. The studded shoes showed that fashion didn’t have to be plain or quiet; it could be loud and bold. Metal studs, which were once used on belts or jackets, made these shoes look strong and different. Punks wore these shoes with ripped jeans and leather jackets to concerts and on the streets. They showed the world that fashion could be a way to share feelings and stand out. These shoes remain a symbol of early punk creativity and confidence.
texts.adult-amateur-short: The studded shoes designed by Vivienne Westwood in 1974 are among her earliest contributions to punk fashion. Westwood’s addition of metal studs to footwear disrupted the conventions of traditional shoe design, turning everyday objects into expressive, subcultural markers. These shoes were part of the radical street style sold at Westwood and Malcolm McLaren’s London boutique during the rise of punk.
texts.adult-amateur-long: The studded shoes designed by Vivienne Westwood in 1974 are among her earliest contributions to punk fashion. Westwood’s addition of metal studs to footwear disrupted the conventions of traditional shoe design, turning everyday objects into expressive, subcultural markers. These shoes were part of the radical street style sold at Westwood and Malcolm McLaren’s London boutique during the rise of punk. In the context of early 1970s London, Vivienne Westwood’s studded shoes represent a design intervention that reframed simple footwear as cultural commentary. Emerging contemporaneously with the boutique later known as SEX, Westwood’s work during this period embraced materials and treatments that signaled defiance and non-conformity. By incorporating metal studs - elements historically linked to functional durability - into shoe design, she subverted conventional notions of refinement and wearability. Instead of smooth, polished surfaces typical of mainstream fashion, these shoes foregrounded raw materials and silhouette disruption. Sold alongside provocative garments in the boutique, they helped define a visual identity that rejected polite dress codes and embraced a vocabulary of punk visual aggression.
texts.adult-expert-short: The studded shoes exemplify early material subversion and symbolic styling in Westwood’s work, where footwear adopts aggressive detailing as a mode of cultural expression. Their construction, integrating metal studs onto soft shoe forms, challenges traditional hierarchies of dress and links accessory design to punk’s broader semiotic framework of resistance.
texts.adult-expert-long: The studded shoes exemplify early material subversion and symbolic styling in Westwood’s work, where footwear adopts aggressive detailing as a mode of cultural expression. Their construction, integrating metal studs onto soft shoe forms, challenges traditional hierarchies of dress and links accessory design to punk’s broader semiotic framework of resistance. The studded shoes occupy a formative position in Westwood’s design trajectory and in the material culture of early punk fashion. Produced in 1974, at a moment when Westwood’s boutique in London was transforming youth street style, these shoes exemplify how accessories became vehicles for ideological expression as much as functional objects. From a technical standpoint, the integration of metal studs onto traditional footwear represents a deliberate disruption of normative design: studs, historically associated with utilitarian or protective equipment, are recontextualized as decorative and confrontational. This choice destabilizes conventional expectations of shoe aesthetics and signals a break from refinement toward a vocabulary of visual defiance. Stylistically, the shoes were often paired with other emblematic elements of early punk ensembles, including bondage trousers, leather jackets, and slogan tees, establishing a cohesive subcultural look. In doing so, the shoes served not merely as accouterments but as semiotic anchors that reinforced the movement’s rejection of mainstream fashion norms. Their influence extends into later runway presentations and retrospective exhibitions that trace the lineage of Westwood’s work, showing how early punk ethos informed her subsequent exploration of historical references, silhouette manipulation, and cultural commentary in fashion design.

texts.kid-amateur-short: The Destroy T-shirt is a famous punk shirt made by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren in 1977. It has the big word “DESTROY” printed on the front, along with other powerful images and words that were meant to surprise people. It was sold in their London shop Seditionaries and was worn by fans of punk music. This shirt helped make punk style very bold and very loud.
texts.kid-amateur-long: The Destroy T-shirt is a famous punk shirt made by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren in 1977. It has the big word “DESTROY” printed on the front, along with other powerful images and words that were meant to surprise people. It was sold in their London shop Seditionaries and was worn by fans of punk music. This shirt helped make punk style very bold and very loud. Vivienne and Malcolm wanted to make clothes that made people think differently about fashion and the world. The Destroy T-shirt was made of simple cotton but decorated with huge letters and strong pictures that looked unusual for clothes at that time. Punk music was about breaking rules and being free, and this shirt showed that idea without using quiet or safe pictures. People who loved punk music wore it to concerts and on the street to show they felt brave and different. The shirt helped show that fashion could be fun, expressive, and even a little shocking. It became a symbol of how punk fashion let people show who they were with bold words and pictures.
texts.kid-expert-short: The Destroy T-shirt, created in 1977 by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren, is one of the most iconic items of early punk fashion. It was made from cotton and included shocking printed graphics and words that reflected punk’s rebellious spirit. The shirt was sold through their boutique and became a powerful symbol of the movement that changed fashion forever.
texts.kid-expert-long: The Destroy T-shirt, created in 1977 by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren, is one of the most iconic items of early punk fashion. It was made from cotton and included shocking printed graphics and words that reflected punk’s rebellious spirit. The shirt was sold through their boutique and became a powerful symbol of the movement that changed fashion forever. In the mid-1970s, Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren were making clothes that matched the loud and rebellious sounds of punk rock. The Destroy T-shirt was one of those creations. The design didn’t try to be calm or pretty; instead it showed big letters and bold images that made people stop and look. Punk fans loved it because it made them feel strong and different. Wearing the shirt meant more than just wearing a piece of cotton. It meant showing that you didn’t follow old rules and that you wanted something new and exciting. This shirt helped make punk fashion a big part of how young people saw themselves.
texts.adult-amateur-short: The Destroy T-shirt (1977) by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren is a seminal punk artifact that captures the raw visual language of the subculture. Created during the heyday of their Seditionaries boutique in London, the shirt employs provocative typography and imagery to confront social norms. The piece was produced in cotton with extended silhouette features typical of the era’s DIY aesthetic.
texts.adult-amateur-long: The Destroy T-shirt (1977) by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren is a seminal punk artifact that captures the raw visual language of the subculture. Created during the heyday of their Seditionaries boutique in London, the shirt employs provocative typography and imagery to confront social norms. The piece was produced in cotton with extended silhouette features typical of the era’s DIY aesthetic. Emerging from Westwood and McLaren’s Seditionaries boutique, the Destroy T-shirt represents a key moment in the visual evolution of punk fashion. The graphic, anchored by the word “DESTROY” printed boldly across the front, was designed to provoke and disrupt. Punk was not only a musical movement but also a cultural rebellion that challenged mainstream values through music, attitude, and style. By placing confrontational language and imagery on cotton muslin, Westwood and McLaren transformed everyday clothing into a medium of critique. Sold alongside other radical designs in their London shop, the shirt became a marker of identity for punks who rejected polished fashion in favor of expressive, provocative garments. This T-shirt remains emblematic of how clothing can channel social sentiment and artistic defiance.
texts.adult-expert-short: The Destroy T-shirt functions as a semiotic object, where printed language and image operate as cultural critique. Its placement within the early punk lexicon reflects a deliberate anti-fashion strategy, repurposing domestic materials and screen-print graphics to destabilize expectations of decorum and taste.
texts.adult-expert-long: The Destroy T-shirt functions as a semiotic object, where printed language and image operate as cultural critique. Its placement within the early punk lexicon reflects a deliberate anti-fashion strategy, repurposing domestic materials and screen-print graphics to destabilize expectations of decorum and taste. The Destroy T-shirt occupies a pivotal role in the narrative of British punk fashion, where apparel transcends utility to function as cultural text. Produced in 1977 by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren during the peak of their Seditionaries influence, the shirt embodies a confluence of graphic subversion and sartorial rebellion. Visually, the shirt’s bold typographic intervention - the word “DESTROY” - is compounded by confrontational imagery, aligning with punk’s rejection of complacency and conventional aesthetics. It belongs to a family of screen-printed garments that circulated through Seditionaries, where extended silhouettes and raw finishes echoed the movement’s anti-establishment ethos. This approach treated clothing not as mere ornament but as communicative artifact, akin to protest graphics or zine culture. By deploying language and arresting imagery on cotton, Westwood and McLaren challenged the dominant paradigms of fashion production and consumption. In its historical context, this T-shirt resonates with other punk signifiers, such as torn denim, safety pins, and DIY customization, advancing a bricolage of materials and meanings that would echo into later high fashion interpretations of punk. Placed today within museum collections and scholarly discourse, the Destroy T-shirt stands as evidence of how punk aesthetics have been formalized and historicized, even as they retain their original intent to provoke, disrupt, and unsettle.

texts.kid-amateur-short: This is a photograph of Vivienne Westwood taken by the famous photographer Martin Parr in 2012. In the picture, Vivienne is wearing a bold shirt that shows she cared about the world - not just clothes! She worked for things like protecting the planet and helping people be treated fairly. Vivienne used fashion to share her ideas, like wearing a special shirt with a message so everyone could see it.
texts.kid-amateur-long: This is a photograph of Vivienne Westwood taken by the famous photographer Martin Parr in 2012. In the picture, Vivienne is wearing a bold shirt that shows she cared about the world - not just clothes! She worked for things like protecting the planet and helping people be treated fairly. Vivienne used fashion to share her ideas, like wearing a special shirt with a message so everyone could see it. Vivienne Westwood was a fashion designer who did amazing clothes, but she also loved helping the Earth and people. In this photo, she wears a shirt that tells us she cared about big things like climate change and fairness. Vivienne believed that clothes are not just for looking nice: they can be used to share important messages! She talked about how we should take care of the world, the animals, and each other. This picture shows how Vivienne used her fashion ideas to help make the world better, which is why many people remember her not only for her clothes, but also for her big heart.
texts.kid-expert-short: This portrait by Martin Parr shows Vivienne Westwood when she was older but still full of ideas and energy. She wore fashion that had strong messages about things like taking care of the planet and fairness for all people. Vivienne used shirts, shows, and speeches to talk about the Earth and how we should all work together to help it.
texts.kid-expert-long: This portrait by Martin Parr shows Vivienne Westwood when she was older but still full of ideas and energy. She wore fashion that had strong messages about things like taking care of the planet and fairness for all people. Vivienne used shirts, shows, and speeches to talk about the Earth and how we should all work together to help it. Vivienne wasn’t only interested in making clothes: she wanted to make a difference in the world.She cared about the environment and people’s rights, and she used what she made to tell those stories. In this picture, her shirt shows that fashion can be more than just pretty clothes; it can be a way to share messages about taking care of the Earth. She worked with big groups like Greenpeace and others to help protect places like the Arctic. Vivienne believed that if people wore clothes with messages and talked about important things, they could help others understand why the planet and fairness are important.
texts.adult-amateur-short: This portrait of Vivienne Westwood by Martin Parr (2012) captures her not just as a fashion designer but as a cultural activist. Here she wears a shirt with a visible message, illustrating how she employed fashion and public appearance to engage with issues such as climate change, human rights, and social justice. Westwood’s work increasingly blurred the line between style and protest, using clothing as a vehicle for advocacy rather than mere adornment.
texts.adult-amateur-long: This portrait of Vivienne Westwood by Martin Parr (2012) captures her not just as a fashion designer but as a cultural activist. Here she wears a shirt with a visible message, illustrating how she employed fashion and public appearance to engage with issues such as climate change, human rights, and social justice. Westwood’s work increasingly blurred the line between style and protest, using clothing as a vehicle for advocacy rather than mere adornment. Martin Parr’s portrait of Vivienne Westwood in 2012 emphasizes her dual identity as both a designer and activist. While many remember Westwood for her influence on punk fashion and her innovative use of historical references in couture, by the 2010s she had become equally recognized for her commitment to political and environmental causes. In this image, the shirt she wears operates as a subtle but clear signifier of her beliefs, reflecting her efforts to bring attention to issues such as climate emergency, over-consumption, and grassroots activism. Throughout this period, Westwood leveraged fashion shows, public appearances, and even clothing graphics to amplify her advocacy, transcending traditional fashion boundaries to communicate urgency and dissent. This portrait thus documents not just a moment frozen in time but a designer whose personal style and activism were inseparable, demonstrating that fashion can serve as a platform for social and ecological commentary.
texts.adult-expert-short: Martin Parr’s 2012 portrait engages with the intersection of fashion iconography and political agency, portraying Westwood as a figure whose sartorial choices were inseparable from her activist rhetoric. Her shirt, worn in a public and artistic context, exemplifies how garments and imagery functioned as semiotic extensions of her advocacy, particularly regarding climate and human rights.
texts.adult-expert-long: Martin Parr’s 2012 portrait engages with the intersection of fashion iconography and political agency, portraying Westwood as a figure whose sartorial choices were inseparable from her activist rhetoric. Her shirt, worn in a public and artistic context, exemplifies how garments and imagery functioned as semiotic extensions of her advocacy, particularly regarding climate and human rights. Martin Parr’s photograph of Vivienne Westwood from 2012 can be read as a visual manifesto, capturing a designer who had long reconfigured fashion as a medium of cultural intervention. By this stage in her career, Westwood had codified her belief that fashion must transcend mere aesthetics to engage with socio-political crises; she once stated that her purpose was to use fashion as a “vehicle for activism,” particularly in the realm of climate change and environmental justice.  The shirt she wears in this portrait is emblematic of this ethos: it is not an arbitrary choice but a deliberate extension of her activist lexicon, aligning her personal identity with her public campaign work. Over the preceding decade, she collaborated with NGOs such as Greenpeace, designed logos for the Save the Arctic campaign, and launched the Climate Revolution movement, all of which foregrounded ecological advocacy within and beyond fashion circles. In this image, the convergence of Westwood’s sartorial authority and her political message is further illuminated by Parr’s photographic style, which tends to emphasize cultural identity and social commentary. The portrait thus situates Westwood not merely as a subject of fashion history but as an agent of cultural discourse, whose clothing choices operate as textual and visual arguments. This framing underscores how Westwood’s sartorial practice in the 21st century remained deeply rooted in political engagement: fashion, for her, was never neutral. Through public imagery, runway interventions, and personal appearance, she articulated a sustained critique of consumer culture, ecological neglect, and institutional inertia, a legacy that the 2012 portrait by Parr encapsulates.

historical.title: Chronicles of Fashion
historical.description: Chronicles of Fashion unfolds as a chronological narrative that situates Vivienne Westwood’s work within a broader cultural and historical continuum. The collection begins with the French artistic and historical references that inspired her vision and then progresses through her most emblematic punk designs, to conclude with her presence in contemporary media and popular culture, from Sex & The City and Nana to significant examples of her public activism. Collectively, these works trace not only the evolution of a designer, but the establishment of an enduring cultural legacy.

made-by.title: Made by Vivienne
made-by.description: Made by Vivienne is a deep dive into the creative genius of Dame Vivienne Westwood, presenting only the works she personally conceived and brought into being. From the raw energy of punk rebellion to refined tailoring and historical reinterpretation, each item embodies her revolutionary approach to fashion, transforming traditional forms such as the corset and Scottish tartan into symbols of power and innovation. Beyond their aesthetic impact, these works also carry her enduring commitment to activism, integrating social and environmental protest into the very fabric of design. Together, they reveal a vision defined not just by garments, but by the principles and audacity that make every object unmistakably Made by Vivienne.

past-future.title: Past and Future
past-future.description: Past and Future traces the interplay of references that shaped Vivienne Westwood’s distinctive vision, bringing together the works that informed her creativity, the designs that emerged from those influences, and the cultural echoes her style continues to generate. Starting with the historical and artistic references that nourished her imagination, the collection moves into the garments and accessories that exemplify her transformative approach to tradition, before closing with the many afterlives of her designs in contemporary media and popular culture, from the iconic wedding gown worn by Carrie Bradshaw in Sex and the City to the striking appearances of Westwood’s creations in Nana, alongside records that witness her public activism and irreverence. Overall, the collection aims at revealing the continuous exchange between past reference and future expression within Westwood’s creative universe.
